examples there of how to build the micro-services architecture it's really state of the art I think this is
becoming an interesting area and we're going to talk about next is another superpower power of invisibility we want
to be able to forget about certain things you can think about cloud as making datacenters invisible it really
needs to know where they are or anything about the buildings right but let's look
at going in a bit deeper this often looking at micro services why do people
are in why people interested in micro services we want to break things up so that we can scale things independently
we want to deploy things independently we want independent security and
permissions think about a monolithic application and one corner of that
application has some critical nature and it's a some credit card processing any
time you touch that application the whole thing has to be dealt with at the level of criticality to do with PCI
compliance and things like that if you break the application up and make just one small piece of it deal with credit
cards and most of the application is dealing with the user experience that makes it much easier to iterate and go
much faster and deal with any issues that you you can basically segregate your system
maybe even run it in a different account run it in a different security I mean a different set of deployment criteria for
your most critical pieces of your application which hopefully change slowly and you're very careful with and
you can iterate and go incredibly fast on the rest of your application where you want to experiment and get out of
the way of the developers that's really the key thing and that that's why micro services have become important that's
why back in 2009 thirty ten when I was a Netflix we went from a monolithic
architecture to a micro services architecture it was just getting too difficult to jam together all these
disparate pieces into one monolithic application so the when you do this
split up you take them on application you take it into services you take the micro services you've now about many
more things to deploy and getting your arms around how to do that has become us
being one of the interesting areas of philosophy is we've seen containers come up and become really the default way
that people manage their micro services and break things into small chunks but
when you're running containers today there's a lot of challenges cluster management scaling the fault tolerance
and securing your environment and there's a lot of work required on top of
you know I got you my my containers is very easy to build the developer builds containers but if you're referring to
operate large numbers of them in a highly secure manner in production there's a lot of work needed so we built
the ec2 container service really to give you a platform for running containers
l introduction it's always from the beginning being oriented around solving that particular problem and it not only
gives you container management in a container registry it gives you the ability to manage an underlying pool of
AWS instances very easily and then it gives you access to EBS box storage it
gives you access to the network it gives you I am roles per container and network
interfaces per container this is really relatively hard to do and it's something
that other container platforms don't do and they don't integrate well into the AWS capabilities so if you're using
roles to control who's allowed to do what to download just the keys that this
service is supposed to have so they can access just the services that is supposed to be able to talk to those
roles need to go down to an individual container it's no good just having them at the instance level so that all the
containers on that instance get share the same sense of permissions so very detailed fine-grained control is
important here so that's the integration that I am and then we have other things
here like a lot batch integration if you're running long term long-running processes you want to change your
passion ops together we have AWS patch which is a high level service that runs on top of ECS it makes CCS kind of

up it's multi zone you just set up your Republic machines across multiple zones
you're not trying to federate together multiple installations of VCs it's an integrated thing within one
region it gives you the capability to survivor zone any issues in one zone where you can just keep running so
that's really important and it's one of the reasons why ECS is used by some of our largest
customers to run really significant installations on container of container
deployments so at the bottom we have to
contain the services we integrate on top of that cloud work so you get logs automatically per container you get your

provisioning or management it scales with usage it you never pay for idle
time and fault-tolerance is built in what it means is that instead of trying
to optimize the workload for a fixed amount of compute the compute expands
and contracts by the second with whatever you're trying to do if you're trying to let's just pick an example
let's say there's a TV advert with a URL to your website in it and you've
scheduled it to be in some really really sort of you know after some really cool show that everyone's going to be
watching you don't know how many people are going to go visit that website you could provision something you could
guess you could stand it up you could test it and it's fairly expensive to leave a large scale system that may be
too big or it may be not big enough you don't know with lambda you just set it up as a set of lambda functions and when
the customers turn up it scales to exactly the right size and as soon as they go away it shrinks down again it
costs a tiny fraction you know ordered several orders of magnitude less to
deploy these very spiky workloads so instead of building businesses where
you're trying to optimize your workloads to fit any constant amount of capacity what happens when you can turn
on his head and say I can deliberately optimize build my business for spikey
workloads I could build a business around people scoring goals in sports events right in a football match you

there as traffic rolls into it at all the scales up as you go the networking
supports this and the security models support it on top of that we have step

and build on top of that we actually already starting to see some startups
